<p><b>Shihoko Ishii</b> (<a href="/wiki/index.php?title=Japanese_language&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese language (page does not exist)">Japanese</a>: <span lang="ja">石井志保子</span>, born 1950)<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> is a Japanese mathematician and professor at the University of Tokyo.  Her research area is <a href="/wiki/Algebraic_geometry" title="Algebraic geometry">algebraic geometry</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2>
<p>Ishii received her bachelor's degree from Tokyo Women's Christian University in 1973 and her master's degree from Waseda University in 1975.  She earned her PhD from Tokyo Metropolitan University in 1983.<sup id="cite_ref-europeansociety_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-europeansociety-3">[3]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Research">Research</span></h2>
<p>Ishii's research focuses on <a href="/wiki/Singularity_theory" title="Singularity theory">singularity theory</a>.  She studies arc spaces, a mathematical concept related to <a href="/wiki/Jet_(mathematics)" title="Jet (mathematics)">jets</a>: arc spaces are <a href="/wiki/Algebraic_variety" title="Algebraic variety">varieties</a> encapsulating information about curves on another variety.<sup id="cite_ref-europeansociety_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-europeansociety-3">[3]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards_and_honours">Awards and honours</span></h2>
<p>Ishii received the Saruhashi Prize for accomplishments by a Japanese woman researcher in the natural sciences in 1995.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup>  As a postdoc, Ishii was inspired by reading a profile of <a href="/wiki/Biography:Fumiko_Yonezawa" title="Biography:Fumiko Yonezawa">Fumiko Yonezawa</a>, a physicist and former winner of the Saruhashi prize.<sup id="cite_ref-europeansociety_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-europeansociety-3">[3]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ishii received the Algebra Prize from the Mathematical Society of Japan in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p>
